source.8e16eb24:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns

plt.figure(figsize=(10,8))
plt.hist(cdf["Rating"])
plt.xlabel("Rating")
plt.show()
source.c6965361:
sns.boxplot(x="Category", y="Rating", data=cdf)
plt.tight_layout()
plt.xticks(rotation="vertical")
plt.axhline(cdf["Rating"].median(), color="red")
plt.show()
source.cacb4efa:
fig, axes=plt.subplots(1,2)

cdf[cdf["Category"] == "ART_AND_DESIGN"]["Rating"].plot(kind="hist", ax=axes[0])
cdf[cdf["Category"] == "TOOLS"]["Rating"].plot(kind="hist", ax=axes[1])

axes[0].title.set_text("Art And Design")
axes[1].title.set_text("Tools")
source.67e5d932:
plt.figure(figsize=(10,10))
X = cdf[cdf["Price"] > 0.0]["Category"]
sns.boxplot(x=X, y="Rating", data=cdf)
plt.xticks(rotation="vertical")
plt.axhline(cdf["Rating"].median(), color="red")
plt.show()
source.c19daedb: The heatmap shows there is approximately no correlation between the size, price, reviews and rating.
source.2a5d21d2: There are 485 records that are last updated before 2015 and need to be updated.
source.b64a8d84: So most of the apps which were not free have high ratings. It means people who paid towards their apps were not unhappy about their products.
